017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ipt_hq;
018
019import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.FloatColors;
020import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.BitConversion;
021import com.github.tommyettinger.digital.MathTools;
022
023import java.util.Random;
024
025/**
026 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the IPT color space.
027 * IPT has more perceptually-uniform handling of hue than some other color spaces, like YCwCm, and this version goes
028 * further than {@link com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.pure.ipt the IPT package} by performing gamma correction and all the
029 * complex exponential adjustments to various components that the original IPT paper used. In most regards, this is a
030 * more thoroughly-constructed color space than YCwCm, but YCwCm may still be useful because of how it maps to aesthetic
031 * components of color. See {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)} for docs on the I, P, and T channels.
032 */
033public class ColorTools {
034        /**
035         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, I (intensity or lightness), P
036         * (protan, a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish), T (tritan, a chromatic component ranging from
037         * bluish to yellowish), and A (alpha or opacity). Intensity should be between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for
038         * very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light colors (almost only white). Protan and tritan
039         * range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5. There's some aesthetic value in changing
040         * just one chroma value. When protan is high and tritan is low, the color is more purple/magenta, when both are low
041         * it is more bluish, when tritan is high and protan is low, the color tends to be greenish, and when both are high
042         * it tends to be orange. When protan and tritan are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.  Alpha is the
043         * multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
044         * <br>
045         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
046         * intensity, protan, and tritan, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original I,
047         * P, and T values if the original values were in the range that {@link #intensity(float)}, {@link #protan(float)},
048         * and {@link #tritan(float)} return. You can use {@link #inGamut(float, float, float)} to check if a given set of
049         * I, P, and T values is in-gamut, that is, it can be converted to and from an RGB color without going out of the
050         * valid range. If you just want to enforce that a color is in-gamut, you can use
051         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}, which takes the same parameters this method does, or
052         * {@link #limitToGamut(float)} if you already have a packed float color that could be out-of-gamut.
053         *
054         * @param intens     0f to 1f, intensity or I component of IPT, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
055         * @param protan     0f to 1f, protan or P component of IPT, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
056         * @param tritan     0f to 1f, tritan or T component of IPT, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
057         * @param alpha      0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque 
058         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
059         */
060        public static float ipt(float intens, float protan, float tritan, float alpha) {
061                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (tritan * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
062                                | ((int) (protan * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (intens * 255) & 0xFF));
063        }
064
065
066        /**
067         * Used when converting from RGB to IPT, as an intermediate step.
068         * @param component one of the LMS channels to be converted to LMS Prime
069         * @return an LMS Prime channel value, which can be converted to IPT
070         */
071        private static float forwardTransform(final float component) {
072                return (float)Math.pow(component, 0.43f);
073        }
074
075        /**
076         * Used when converting from IPT to RGB, as an intermediate step.
077         * @param component one of the LMS Prime channels to be converted to LMS
078         * @return an LMS channel value, which can be converted to RGB
079         */
080        private static float reverseTransform(final float component) {
081                return Math.copySign((float)Math.pow(Math.abs(component), 2.3256f), component);
082        }
083
084        /**
085         * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, approximating with gamma 2.0.
086         * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
087         * @return a linear version of component
088         */
089        private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
090                return component * component;
091        }
092
093        /**
094         * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using gamma 2.0.
095         * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
096         * @return a non-linear version of component
097         */
098        private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
099                return (float)Math.sqrt(component);
100        }
101
102
103        /**
104         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
105         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
106         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
107         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
108         */
109        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
110        {
111                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
112                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
113                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
114                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
115                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
116                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
117                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
118                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
119                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
120                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
121                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
122        }
123
124        /**
125         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
126         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
127         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
128         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#ipt(float, float, float, float)}
129         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
130         */
131        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
132        {
133                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
134                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
135                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
136                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
137                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
138                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
139                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
140                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
141                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
142                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
143                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
144        }
145
146        /**
147         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
148         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
149         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
150         */
151        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
152                final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
153                final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
154                final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
155                final float l = forwardTransform(0.313921f * r + 0.639468f * g + 0.0465970f * b);
156                final float m = forwardTransform(0.151693f * r + 0.748209f * g + 0.1000044f * b);
157                final float s = forwardTransform(0.017753f * r + 0.109468f * g + 0.8729690f * b);
158                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
159                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4000f * l + 0.4000f * m + 0.2000f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0), 255)
160                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((2.2275f * l - 2.4255f * m + 0.1980f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8
161                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4028f * l + 0.1786f * m - 0.5814f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16
162                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
163        }
164
165        /**
166         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
167         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
168         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
169         */
170        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
171                final int abgr = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
172                final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
173                final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
174                final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
175                final float l = forwardTransform(0.313921f * r + 0.639468f * g + 0.0465970f * b);
176                final float m = forwardTransform(0.151693f * r + 0.748209f * g + 0.1000044f * b);
177                final float s = forwardTransform(0.017753f * r + 0.109468f * g + 0.8729690f * b);
178                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
179                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4000f * l + 0.4000f * m + 0.2000f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0), 255)
180                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((2.2275f * l - 2.4255f * m + 0.1980f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8
181                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4028f * l + 0.1786f * m - 0.5814f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16
182                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
183        }
184
185        /**
186         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the IPT format this uses.
187         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
188         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
189         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
190         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
191         * @return a packed float as IPT, which this class can use
192         */
193        public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
194                r = forwardGamma(r);
195                g = forwardGamma(g);
196                b = forwardGamma(b);
197                final float l = forwardTransform(0.313921f * r + 0.639468f * g + 0.0465970f * b);
198                final float m = forwardTransform(0.151693f * r + 0.748209f * g + 0.1000044f * b);
199                final float s = forwardTransform(0.017753f * r + 0.109468f * g + 0.8729690f * b);
200                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(
201                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4000f * l + 0.4000f * m + 0.2000f * s       ) * 255.999f), 0), 255)
202                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((2.2275f * l - 2.4255f * m + 0.1980f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 8
203                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.4028f * l + 0.1786f * m - 0.5814f * s + 0.5f) * 255.999f), 0), 255) << 16
204                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
205        }
206
207        /**
208         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
209         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
210         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
211         */
212        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
213        {
214                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
215                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
216                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
217                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
218                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
219                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
220                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
221                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
222        }
223
224        /**
225         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
226         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
227         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
228         */
229        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
230        {
231                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
232                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
233                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
234                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
235                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
236                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
237                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
238                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
239        }
240
241        /**
242         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
243         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
244         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
245         */
246        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
247        {
248                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
249                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
250                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
251                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
252                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
253                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
254                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
255                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
256        }
257
258        /**
259         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
260         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
261         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
262         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
263         */
264        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
265        {
266                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
267        }
268
269        /**
270         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
271         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
272         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
273         */
274        public static float red(final float encoded)
275        {
276                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
277                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
278                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
279                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
280                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
281                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
282                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
283                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f));
284        }
285
286        /**
287         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
288         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
289         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
290         */
291        public static float green(final float encoded)
292        {
293                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
294                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
295                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
296                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
297                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
298                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
299                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
300                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f));
301        }
302
303        /**
304         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
305         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
306         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
307         */
308        public static float blue(final float encoded)
309        {
310                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
311                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
312                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
313                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
314                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
315                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
316                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
317                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f));
318        }
319
320        /**
321         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
322         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
323         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
324         */
325        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
326        {
327                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
328        }
329
330        /**
331         * Gets a color as an IPT packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
332         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
333         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
334         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
335         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
336         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
337         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
338         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
339         *
340         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
341         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
342         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
343         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
344         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
345         */
346        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
347                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
348                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
349                } else {
350                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
351                }
352        }
353
354        /**
355         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
356         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
357         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
358         */
359        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
360                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
361                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
362                if(Math.abs(i - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
363                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
364                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
365                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
366                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
367                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
368                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f));
369                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f));
370                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f));
371                float x, y, w;
372                if(g < b) {
373                        x = b;
374                        y = g;
375                }
376                else {
377                        x = g;
378                        y = b;
379                }
380                if(r < x) {
381                        w = r;
382                }
383                else {
384                        w = x;
385                        x = r;
386                }
387                return x - Math.min(w, y);
388        }
389
390        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
391                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
392                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
393                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
394                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
395                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
396                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
397                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
398                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f));
399                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f));
400                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f));
401
402                float x, y, w;
403                if(g < b) {
404                        x = b;
405                        y = g;
406                }
407                else {
408                        x = g;
409                        y = b;
410                }
411                if(r < x) {
412                        w = r;
413                }
414                else {
415                        w = x;
416                        x = r;
417                }
418                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
419                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
420        }
421
422        /**
423         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
424         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased).
425         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
426         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
427         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
428         */
429        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
430                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
431                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
432                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
433                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
434                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
435                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
436                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
437                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f));
438                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f));
439                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f));
440                float x, y, z, w;
441                if(g < b) {
442                        x = b;
443                        y = g;
444                        z = -1f;
445                        w = 2f / 3f;
446                }
447                else {
448                        x = g;
449                        y = b;
450                        z = 0f;
451                        w = -1f / 3f;
452                }
453                if(r < x) {
454                        z = w;
455                        w = r;
456                }
457                else {
458                        w = x;
459                        x = r;
460                }
461                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
462                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
463        }
464
465        /**
466         * The "intensity" of the given packed float in IPT format, which is like its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
467         * 1.0f . You can edit the intensity of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and
468         * {@link #darken(float, float)}.
469         *
470         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
471         * @return the intensity value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
472         */
473        public static float intensity(final float encoded)
474        {
475                return (BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
476        }
477
478        /**
479         * The "protan" of the given packed float in IPT format, which when combined with tritan describes the
480         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If protan is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
481         * blue; if protan is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the protan of a color with
482         * {@link #protanUp(float, float)} and {@link #protanDown(float, float)}.
483         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
484         * @return the protan value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
485         */
486        public static float protan(final float encoded)
487        {
488                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
489        }
490
491        /**
492         * The "tritan" of the given packed float in IPT format, which when combined with protan describes the
493         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If tritan is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
494         * blue or purple; if tritan is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
495         * the tritan of a color with {@link #tritanUp(float, float)} and {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}.
496         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
497         * @return the tritan value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
498         */
499        public static float tritan(final float encoded)
500        {
501                return ((BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
502        }
503
504        /**
505         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
506         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not IPT_HQ! Takes
507         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
508         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color. The float is
509         * likely to be different than the result of {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation,
510         * lightness, and opacity are all 0. This won't allocate any objects.
511         * <br>
512         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
513         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
514         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
515         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
516         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
517         *
518         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
519         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
520         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
521         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
522         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
523         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
524         */
525        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
526                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
527                final float i = Math.min(Math.max(light + (e & 0xff) / 255f, 0f), 1f);
528                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (e >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
529                if (i <= 0.001f)
530                        return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
531                final float p = ((e >>> 7 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 255f;
532                final float t = ((e >>> 15 & 0x1fe) - 0xff) / 255f;
533                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
534                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
535                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
536                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s, 0f), 1f));
537                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s, 0f), 1f));
538                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s, 0f), 1f));
539                float x, y, z, w;
540                if(g < b) {
541                        x = b;
542                        y = g;
543                        z = -1f;
544                        w = 2f / 3f;
545                }
546                else {
547                        x = g;
548                        y = b;
549                        z = 0f;
550                        w = -1f / 3f;
551                }
552                if(r < x) {
553                        z = w;
554                        w = r;
555                }
556                else {
557                        w = x;
558                        x = r;
559                }
560                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
561                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
562                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
563                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
564                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
565        }
566
567        /**
568         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
569         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
570         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
571         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
572         * towards white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both
573         * chroma of start as-is. This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some
574         * changes with this or other component-editing methods (like {@link #protanUp(float, float)} or
575         * {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}), you may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can
576         * be rendered correctly.
577         *
578         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
579         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
580         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
581         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
582         */
583        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
584                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
585                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
586        }
587
588        /**
589         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
590         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
591         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
592         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
593         * towards white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both
594         * chroma of start as-is. This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some
595         * changes with this or other component-editing methods (like {@link #protanUp(float, float)} or
596         * {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}), you may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can
597         * be rendered correctly.
598         *
599         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
600         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
601         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
602         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
603         */
604        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
605                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
606                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
607        }
608
609        /**
610         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
611         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
612         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
613         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
614         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
615         * alpha and intensity of start as-is.
616         * This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some changes with this or
617         * other component-editing methods (like {@link #lighten(float, float)} or {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}), you
618         * may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can be rendered correctly.
619         *
620         * @see #protanDown(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
621         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
622         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
623         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
624         */
625        public static float protanUp(final float start, final float change) {
626                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
627                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
628        }
629
630        /**
631         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
632         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
633         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
634         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
635         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
636         * intensity of start as-is.
637         * This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some changes with this or
638         * other component-editing methods (like {@link #lighten(float, float)} or {@link #tritanDown(float, float)}), you
639         * may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can be rendered correctly.
640         *
641         * @see #protanUp(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
642         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
643         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
644         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
645         */
646        public static float protanDown(final float start, final float change) {
647                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
648                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
649        }
650
651        /**
652         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
653         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
654         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
655         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
656         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
657         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and intensity of start as-is.
658         * This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some changes with this or
659         * other component-editing methods (like {@link #protanUp(float, float)} or {@link #darken(float, float)}), you
660         * may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can be rendered correctly.
661         *
662         * @see #tritanDown(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
663         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
664         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
665         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
666         */
667        public static float tritanUp(final float start, final float change) {
668                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
669                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
670        }
671
672        /**
673         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
674         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
675         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
676         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
677         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
678         * alpha and intensity of start as-is.
679         * This method does not necessarily keep the resulting color in-gamut; after performing some changes with this or
680         * other component-editing methods (like {@link #protanUp(float, float)} or {@link #darken(float, float)}), you
681         * may want to call {@link #limitToGamut(float)} to make sure the color can be rendered correctly.
682         *
683         * @see #tritanUp(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
684         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
685         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
686         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
687         */
688        public static float tritanDown(final float start, final float change) {
689                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
690                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
691        }
692
693        /**
694         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
695         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
696         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
697         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
698         * towards transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
699         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
700         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
701         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
702         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
703         */
704        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
705                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
706                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
707        }
708
709        /**
710         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
711         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
712         * {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
713         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
714         * transparent. This won't change the intensity, protan, or tritan of the color.
715         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
716         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
717         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
718         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
719         */
720        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
721                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
722                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
723        }
724
725        /**
726         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
727         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
728         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes protan and tritan; it leaves intensity and alpha
729         * alone, unlike {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes intensity.
730         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
731         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
732         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
733         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
734         */
735        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
736                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
737                return ipt((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
738                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
739                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
740                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
741        }
742
743        /**
744         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
745         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
746         * from {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}. This usually changes only protan and tritan, but higher values for
747         * {@code change} can force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using
748         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)} (and that can change intensity somewhat). If the color stays
749         * in-gamut, then intensity won't change; alpha never changes.
750         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
751         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
752         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
753         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
754         */
755        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
756                final int s = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(start);
757                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
758                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
759                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
760                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
761        }
762
763
764        /**
765         * Given a packed float IPT color {@code mainColor} and another IPT color that it should be made to contrast with,
766         * gets a packed float IPT color with roughly inverted intnsity but the same chromatic channels and opacity (P and T
767         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
768         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for intensity values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
769         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
770         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the intensity unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
771         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
772         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
773         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
774         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
775         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}; this is the color that will be adjusted
776         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
777         * @return a different IPT packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
778         */
779        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
780        {
781                final int bits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
782                                contrastBits = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
783                                i = (bits & 0xff),
784                                p = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
785                                t = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
786                                ci = (contrastBits & 0xff),
787                                cp = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
788                                ct = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
789                if((p - cp) * (p - cp) + (t - ct) * (t - ct) >= 0x10000)
790                        return mainColor;
791                return ipt(ci < 128 ? i * (0.45f / 255f) + 0.55f : 0.5f - i * (0.45f / 255f), p / 255f, t / 255f, 0x1.0p-8f * (bits >>> 24));
792        }
793
794        /**
795         * Given a packed float IPT_HQ color {@code mainColor} and another IPT_HQ color that it should be made to contrast
796         * with, gets a packed float IPT_HQ color with I that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s I,
797         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
798         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
799         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
800         * <br>
801         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
802         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
803         * averages the original I of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
804         * @param mainColor a packed IPT_HQ float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
805         * @param contrastingColor a packed IPT_HQ float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the I of this
806         * @return a different packed IPT_HQ float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
807         */
808        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
809        {
810                final int main = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
811                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
812        }
813
814        /**
815         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's I and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
816         * with the original I. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
817         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
818         * @param mainColor a packed IPT_HQ float color
819         * @return a different packed IPT_HQ float color, with its I channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
820         */
821        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
822                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
823                return limitToGamut(BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFEFFFF00) | (decoded + 128 & 0xFF) + (decoded & 0xFF) >>> 1));
824        }
825
826        /**
827         * Makes the additive IPT color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
828         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
829         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
830         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
831         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
832         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
833         * @return an IPT float color between gray and {@code color}
834         */
835        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
836                final int e = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color),
837                                is = 0x80, ps = 0x80, ts = 0x80,
838                                ie = (e & 0xFF), pe = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, te = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, ae = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
839                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat(((int) (is + fraction * (ie - is)) & 0xFF)
840                                | (((int) (ps + fraction * (pe - ps)) & 0xFF) << 8)
841                                | (((int) (ts + fraction * (te - ts)) & 0xFF) << 16)
842                                | (ae << 24));
843        }
844
845        /**
846         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
847         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
848         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
849         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
850         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the I, P, and T of the
851         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
852         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers P and T extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while I goes from 0 to 1,
853         * but only internally for measuring distance).
854         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #ipt(float, float, float, float)}
855         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
856         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
857         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
858         */
859        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
860                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(color);
861                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
862                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
863                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
864                final float limit = variance * variance;
865                float dist, x, y, z;
866                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
867                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
868                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
869                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
870                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
871                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
872                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += i, y = (p + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (t + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
873                                return BitConversion.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
874                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
875                }
876                return color;
877        }
878
879        /**
880         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as IPT, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
881         * @param packed a packed float color as IPT
882         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
883         */
884        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
885        {
886                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
887                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
888                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
889                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
890                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
891                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
892                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
893
894                final float r = 5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s;
895                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
896                final float g = -1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s;
897                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
898                final float b = 0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s;
899                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
900        }
901        /**
902         * Returns true if the given IPT values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA. 
903         * @param i intensity channel, as a float from 0 to 1
904         * @param p protan channel, as a float from 0 to 1
905         * @param t tritan channel, as a float from 0 to 1
906         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
907         */
908        public static boolean inGamut(float i, float p, float t)
909        {
910                p = (p - 0.5f) * 2f;
911                t = (t - 0.5f) * 2f;
912                final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p + 0.205226f * t);
913                final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p + 0.133217f * t);
914                final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p + -0.67689f * t);
915
916                final float r = 5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s;
917                if(r < 0f || r > 1.0f) return false;
918                final float g = -1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s;
919                if(g < 0f || g > 1.0f) return false;
920                final float b = 0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s;
921                return (b >= 0f && b <= 1.0f);
922        }
923
924        /**
925         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
926         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the intensity of the color, only bringing
927         * protan and tritan closer to grayscale.
928         * @param packed a packed float color in IPT format; often this color is not in-gamut
929         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
930         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
931         */
932        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
933                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
934                final float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
935                final float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
936                final float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
937                float p2 = p, t2 = t;
938                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
939                        final float l = reverseTransform(i + 0.097569f * p2 + 0.205226f * t2);
940                        final float m = reverseTransform(i + -0.11388f * p2 + 0.133217f * t2);
941                        final float s = reverseTransform(i + 0.032615f * p2 + -0.67689f * t2);
942
943                        final float r = 5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s;
944                        final float g = -1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s;
945                        final float b = 0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s;
946                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
947                                break;
948                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
949                        p2 = MathTools.lerp(0, p, progress);
950                        t2 = MathTools.lerp(0, t, progress);
951                }
952                return ipt(i, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, (decoded >>> 25) / 127f);
953        }
954
955        /**
956         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
957         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the intensity of the color, only bringing
958         * protan and tritan closer to grayscale. This always produces an opaque color.
959         * @param i intensity component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
960         * @param p protan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
961         * @param t tritan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
962         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
963         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
964         */
965        public static float limitToGamut(float i, float p, float t) {
966                return limitToGamut(i, p, t, 1f);
967        }
968        /**
969         * Iteratively checks whether the given IPT color is in-gamut, and either brings the color closer to grayscale if it
970         * isn't in-gamut, or returns it as soon as it is in-gamut. Maintains the intensity of the color, only bringing
971         * protan and tritan closer to grayscale.
972         * @param i intensity component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
973         * @param p protan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
974         * @param t tritan component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
975         * @param a alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
976         * @return the first color this finds that is between the given IPT color and grayscale, and is in-gamut
977         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
978         */
979        public static float limitToGamut(float i, float p, float t, float a) {
980                float i2 = Math.min(Math.max(i, 0f), 1f);
981                float p2 = p = Math.min(Math.max((p - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
982                float t2 = t = Math.min(Math.max((t - 0.5f) * 2f, -1f), 1f);
983                a = Math.min(Math.max(a, 0f), 1f);
984                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
985                        final float l = reverseTransform(i2 + 0.097569f * p2 + 0.205226f * t2);
986                        final float m = reverseTransform(i2 + -0.11388f * p2 + 0.133217f * t2);
987                        final float s = reverseTransform(i2 + 0.032615f * p2 + -0.67689f * t2);
988
989                        final float r = 5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s;
990                        final float g = -1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s;
991                        final float b = 0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s;
992                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
993                                break;
994                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
995                        p2 = MathTools.lerp(0, p, progress);
996                        t2 = MathTools.lerp(0, t, progress);
997                }
998                return ipt(i2, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, a);
999        }
1000        /**
1001         * Given a packed float IPT_HQ color, this edits its intensity, protan, tritan, and alpha channels by adding the
1002         * corresponding "add" parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float
1003         * can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This
1004         * clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1005         * @param encoded a packed float IPT_HQ color
1006         * @param addI how much to add to the intensity channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1007         * @param addP how much to add to the protan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
1008         * @param addT how much to add to the tritan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
1009         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1010         * @return a packed float IPT_HQ color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1011         */
1012        public static float editIPT(float encoded, float addI, float addP, float addT, float addAlpha) {
1013                return editIPT(encoded, addI, addP, addT, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
1014        }
1015        /**
1016         * Given a packed float IPT_HQ color, this edits its intensity, protan, tritan, and alpha channels by first
1017         * multiplying each channel by the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter,
1018         * before clamping. This means the intensity value is multiplied by {@code mulI}, then has {@code addI} added, and
1019         * then is clamped to the normal range for intensity (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the
1020         * given float can't be edited in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay
1021         * unchanged, or a value of 1 for any "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates protan and
1022         * tritan in the -1 to 1 range, so if you multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a
1023         * less-saturated color, and if you multiply by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much
1024         * more-saturated color. This clamps the resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back
1025         * to RGBA.
1026         * @param encoded a packed float IPT_HQ color
1027         * @param addI how much to add to the intensity channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1028         * @param addP how much to add to the protan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
1029         * @param addT how much to add to the tritan channel; typically in the -2 to 2 range
1030         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1031         * @param mulI how much to multiply the intensity channel by; should be non-negative
1032         * @param mulP how much to multiply the protan channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1033         * @param mulT how much to multiply the tritan channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1034         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
1035         * @return a packed float IPT_HQ color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1036         */
1037        public static float editIPT(float encoded, float addI, float addP, float addT, float addAlpha,
1038                                                                float mulI, float mulP, float mulT, float mulAlpha) {
1039                final int decoded = BitConversion.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1040                float i = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1041                float p = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1042                float t = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1043                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1044
1045                float i2 = Math.min(Math.max(i * mulI + addI, 0f), 1f);
1046                float p2 = p = Math.min(Math.max(p * mulP + addP, -1f), 1f);
1047                float t2 = t = Math.min(Math.max(t * mulT + addT, -1f), 1f);
1048                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
1049                for (int attempt = 31; attempt >= 0; attempt--) {
1050                        final float l = reverseTransform(i2 + 0.097569f * p2 + 0.205226f * t2);
1051                        final float m = reverseTransform(i2 + -0.11388f * p2 + 0.133217f * t2);
1052                        final float s = reverseTransform(i2 + 0.032615f * p2 + -0.67689f * t2);
1053
1054                        final float r = 5.432622f * l + -4.67910f * m + 0.246257f * s;
1055                        final float g = -1.10517f * l + 2.311198f * m + -0.20588f * s;
1056                        final float b = 0.028104f * l + -0.19466f * m + 1.166325f * s;
1057                        if(r >= 0f && r <= 1f && g >= 0f && g <= 1f && b >= 0f && b <= 1f)
1058                                break;
1059                        final float progress = attempt * 0x1p-5f;
1060                        p2 = MathTools.lerp(0, p, progress);
1061                        t2 = MathTools.lerp(0, t, progress);
1062                }
1063                return ipt(i2, p2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, t2 * 0.5f + 0.5f, alpha);
1064        }
1065
1066        /**
1067         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1068         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
1069         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1070         */
1071        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1072                float i = random.nextFloat();
1073                float p = random.nextFloat();
1074                float t = random.nextFloat();
1075                while (!inGamut(i, p, t)) {
1076                        i = random.nextFloat();
1077                        p = random.nextFloat();
1078                        t = random.nextFloat();
1079                }
1080                return ipt(i, p, t, 1f);
1081        }
1082
1083        /**
1084         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1085         * This is only present for legacy compatibility; new code should use {@link #randomColor(Random)}.
1086         * @param random a Random object (or preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.github.tommyettinger.digital.AlternateRandom})
1087         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1088         * @deprecated Use {@link #randomColor(Random)} instead.
1089         */
1090        @Deprecated
1091        public static float randomizedColor(Random random) {
1092                float i = random.nextFloat();
1093                float p = random.nextFloat();
1094                float t = random.nextFloat();
1095                while (!inGamut(i, p, t)) {
1096                        i = random.nextFloat();
1097                        p = random.nextFloat();
1098                        t = random.nextFloat();
1099                }
1100                return ipt(i, p, t, 1f);
1101        }
